description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Ambassaden har fått en förfrågan av ECOWAS att finansiera projektet "Transitional Support to the ECOWAS Regional Radio" med 11,2 miljoner kronor under perioden juli 2018 till september 2019.
Huvudsyftet med stödet är att tillhandahålla övergångsstöd till ECOWAS Radio som syftar till att bidra till främjandet av lokala fredsbyggande initiativ i Liberia, samtidigt som radions kapacitet stärks för att garantera en smidig expansion till samtliga 15 medlemsländerna i ECOWAS.
Stödet förväntas bidra till att: - ECOWAS förstärker sin operativa kapacitet att arbeta med radiosändning samtidigt som organisationen utvecklar sin kapacitet att expandera sina radiofaciliteter till alla 15 medlemsstater i Västafrika. -ECOWAS använder radio för att skapa strategiska partnerskap med civilsamhällesorganisationer, media och allmänheten för att skapa en plattform för främjande av fred och utveckling i Liberia.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 ECOWAS has applied to The Embassy of Sweden for funding of 11,2 million SEK to carry out the “Transitional Support to the ECOWAS Regional Radio” during July 2018 to September 2019.
The main objective of the intervention is to provide transitional support to the ECOWAS radio that will contribute to the promotion of local peacebuilding initiatives in Liberia, while building the capacity of the radio to guarantee a smooth expansion to cover the 15 countries in the West African sub-region.
Two main outcomes are expected to be achieved by the intervention: - ECOWAS solidifies its operational capability to maintain broadcast of its radio station while developing its capacity to expand its radio facilities to all 15 countries in West Africa; and -ECOWAS Utilizes radio programming to establish strategic partnerships with civil society organizations, other media/communication institutions, and the public so as to create a reliable platform for the promotion of peace and development in Liberia.

The main objective of the intervention is to provide transitional support to ECOWAS Radio. By providing an independant radio station with national coverage, ECOWAS contributes to the promotion of local peacebuilding initiatives in Liberia, while building the capacity of the Radio to guarantee a smooth expansion to cover the 15 countries in the West African sub-region.
Two main outcomes are expected to be achieved by this intervention:
ECOWAS solidifies its operational capability to maintain broadcast of its Radio station while developing its capacity to expand its radio facilities to all 15 countries in West Africa;
ECOWAS utilizes Radio programming to establish strategic partnerships with civil society organizations, other media/communication institutions, and the public so as to create a reliable platform for the promotion of peace and development in Liberia
Following intenral discussions and dialogue with the Embassy as well as Community Radio Network ALICOR, during a six-month extension, ECOWAS have decided on a final exit strategy for the coming two years. ECOWAS are planning to transfer their skills and knowledge to ALICOR, while ensuring that unbiased radio broadscasting is available nation-wide during elections.

description.narrative:
Radio currently serves as the most reliable means of accessing information in Liberia, especially outside the capital Monrovia. However, access to balanced and impartial reporting remains a concern. ECOWAS Radio, with its wide coverage rate reaching most counties in Liberia, is therefore securing non-partisan and neutral access to information as a tool for consolidating peace in Liberia and securing the populations access to credible information.
Some key results include:
The Radio continued to broadcast information of peace, sustainable development and credible and non-partisan news.
The ECOWAS Radio Internet platform has been active.
Community Radio Stations in the 15 Counties are airing ECOWAS Rdio pre-recorded programs and jingles.
ECOWAS Radio has established 102 peace-focused listening circles in particular conflict "hot-spots" in all 15 Counties. These listening circles are a local platform for community dwellers to sit together, listen to radio content produced and use the information to promote community peace and development.
Theater/street performances were conducted on COVID-19, 2020 Elections and Referendum as well as community Radio Dialogue on conflicts issues.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
